Boreskov Institute of Catalysis 5, Lavrentieva Ave. Novosibirsk 630090 Russia Graphical abstract The paper presents the low-temperature nitrogen adsorption, TG, XRD, IR spectroscopy, XPS, TEM and SEM data for ruthenium promoted (0.2–1wt.%) Сo-δAl2O3 catalysts and characteristics of the catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis after their activation under the conditions ensuring the reduction of comparable fractions of metallic cobalt. It was shown that cobalt in oxide precursors is a component of the spinel-like Со3-xAlxO4 phase containing the impurity anions СО3 2−, NO3 −, ОН−, and NO in promoted samples, which belong to the thermolysis product of the Ru precursor. Average sizes of Со3-xAlxO4 crystallites are in a range of 5–10nm. As ruthenium content in the catalyst increases upon reduction, the temperature of metallic phase formation decreases substantially (by more than 150°C). After the reduction, selectivity of promoted catalysts for α-olefins and high-molecular hydrocarbons was higher in comparison with unpromoted catalysts, without a noticeable decrease in catalytic activity. Therewith, in 0.5–1.0wt.% catalysts, a part of ruthenium forms individual ultradispersed metallic particles ca. 1nm in size that are located on the surface of oxide support and are not active in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The oxide layer decorating the surface of metallic cobalt particles is also strongly enriched with ruthenium. In the 0.2wt.% catalyst, the major part of ruthenium resides in metallic cobalt particles. Although the ruthenium-cobalt alloy segregates with enrichment of the surface with cobalt, the presence of ruthenium in the metallic particles and probably in the decorating oxide layer exerts a considerable effect on selectivity of the catalysts. Keywords Cobalt-alumina catalysts Promotion Ruthenium Cobalt-ruthenium alloy Fischer-Tropsch synthesis 1 Introduction Gas-to-liquid technology (GTL) is one of the known processes for the production of liquid synthetic hydrocarbons from natural gas. This technology includes several steps: syngas production from natural gas, syngas conversion to hydrocarbon products via the catalytic Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS), and upgrading of hydrocarbons (hydrocracking and hydroisomerization). The composition of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis products depends on the catalyst features and reaction conditions. It is known that cobalt-containing catalysts are most efficient for the production of linear hydrocarbons with the C5+ chain length at low temperatures and pressures of the synthesis, with low selectivity for the formation of methane (10% and lower), and low activity in WGSR. Supports for such catalysts are commonly represented by inorganic systems with the high specific surface area and sufficient mechanical strength (SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2 and ZrO2). Active catalytic sites of supported cobalt catalysts are nanostructured metallic particles with optimal size from 5 to 10nm [1,2]. The particles are formed by thermal reduction in a hydrogen-containing mixture from the oxide precursor. Metallic particles can be obtained also by direct decomposition of organic salts (cobalt citrate) or other organic precursors in an inert atmosphere (IR pyrolysis of a common solution of polymer and cobalt salt) [3–5]. It is known that thermal reduction of both the bulk Со3О4 and the oxide precursor of any supported cobalt catalyst consists of two steps: Со3О4 * →СоО* and СоО*→Со0 [6–10], where asterisks indicate the possible presence of anions of the precursor compound, cations of the oxide support or promoting metals in the oxide. Temperature intervals and features of the reduction steps depend on the size of oxide particles as well as on the nature and amount of impurity anions and cations, and are caused by the nature of precursor compounds, support, methods and conditions of the synthesis, the presence of promoters, and conditions of thermal treatment. The effect of support nature is clearly demonstrated in the case of strong interaction of alumina with cobalt compounds during thermal decomposition, which leads to the formation of relatively small particles of the active component precursor, on the one hand, and spinel-like compounds with the composition Со3-xAlxO4 (0≤x≤2), on the other hand [11,12]. As a result, the formation of metallic particles via the reduction of cobalt ions in a hydrogen-containing mixture of the indicated compounds proceeds at higher temperatures as compared to the reduction of bulk Со3О4 structure, which is completely reduced at 350–400°C. According to [6,7,13], the appearance of metallic phase upon non-isothermal reduction at a partial hydrogen pressure of 0.1–1atm is observed at a temperature not lower than 400–500°C. A possible way to decrease the activation temperature of cobalt-containing catalysts is the introduction of noble metals, for example Pt, Pd, Ru or Re. Such metals promote cobalt reduction to the metallic state; however, platinum and palladium adversely affect its selectivity owing to their intrinsic activity in CO hydrogenation to methane and light hydrocarbons [14,15]. On the other hand, the introduction of up to 5wt.% ruthenium either slightly decreases or even increases the selectivity of cobalt catalysts for high-molecular hydrocarbons. Several research groups showed earlier [14–20] that the promotion of Co-Al2O3 catalysts with small amounts of ruthenium decreases the characteristic temperature of cobalt reduction by 100–150°C (according to TPR data) and increases initial activity of the catalyst with the retained selectivity for C5+ products. Ruthenium affects also the dispersion of active component particles: the introduction of promoter produces a twofold or even greater increase in the dispersion (according to data of hydrogen chemisorption followed by oxygen titration). In [21], hydrogen chemisorption data indicated that promotion of the cobalt catalyst did not increase the dispersion; however, transmission electron microscopy showed that the fraction of ultradispersed particles (below 6nm) decreased from 83 to 49%, whereas the fraction of particles with the optimal for FTS sizes in the range of 6–12nm increased from 17 to 51%. In all the listed works, the catalytic properties of ruthenium promoted and unpromoted Со-Al catalysts were compared under similar conditions of reductive activation before catalytic testing in FTS: the temperature (350°C [14,15,17,18], 400°C [16,19,21], 420°C [20]) and duration of isothermal mode (10–16h) were the same. Since for unpromoted Co-Al catalysts the temperatures of metallic cobalt particles formation are above 450 °C and ruthenium promotion substantially decreases the cobalt reduction temperature, in all the cited works ruthenium promoted catalysts expectedly showed a higher reduction degree and a greater amount of active metal sites. For example, after 10h of reductive activation at 350°C the fraction of cobalt reduced to metallic state in the 15%Со-Al2О3 catalyst only reached 30% [14]. Therewith, the characteristic temperature of metallic phase formation, according to TPR data, was ca. 600°C. The introduction of 0.5wt.% ruthenium decreased the characteristic temperature by 100°C, thus increasing to 50% the fraction of cobalt reduced to metallic state. In the study of 20% Со-Al2О3 catalyst [18], the fraction of cobalt that was reduced to metallic state by promotion with 0.5wt.% ruthenium increased from 60 to 85% (the characteristic temperature of the reduction process, according to TPR data, decreased from 600 to 450°C). The catalytic activity of such systems in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis is determined by the amount of metallic cobalt; so, the activity was expectedly higher for the promoted catalysts. A comparison of the catalytic properties of Ru promoted and unpromoted Co-Al catalysts that were reduced at optimal (and different) temperatures could reveal the role of ruthenium directly in the catalytic process and separate it from the plausible effect of ruthenium on the reductive activation of Co-Al catalysts. However, such studies were not found in the literature. The study was carried out with the cobalt-alumina FTS catalysts promoted with fac-Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 ruthenium complex or unpromoted. The goal of the work was to compare the catalytic properties of ruthenium promoted and unpromoted Co-Al catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis after their activation under the conditions ensuring the comparable extent of cobalt reduction, and to elucidate the role of ruthenium directly in the catalytic Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Cobalt-alumina catalysts were synthesized using deposition by precipitation with urea (DPU) [22]. The synthesis was carried out with granulated δ-Al2O3 cylinders (diameter 2.5mm, length 4–5mm) that were obtained by thermal treatment of pseudoboehmite in air at 900 °C for 3h (A64, JSC Angarsk Catalysts and Organic Synthesis Plant), Сo(NO3)2·6H2O salt (pure, GOST 4528-78), and urea (analytically pure, GOST 6691-77). 20g of the support suspended in 93ml of an aqueous mixture of cobalt nitrate and urea solutions with the Co2+ concentration 3M and urea concentration 10.8M were vigorously stirred by a paddle stirrer at 90°C and constant volume of suspension for 5h. Upon completion, catalyst granules were separated from the resulting suspension of dispersed Co-Al hydroxycompound, carefully washed with distilled water and dried in air. The anionic composition of the compounds of dry precursors of cobalt-alumina catalysts was earlier reported in [8,22]. Dry precursors of the cobalt catalysts are cobalt-aluminum hydroxy-nitrate-carbonates with a hydrotalcite-like structure and the content of anions depending on initial concentrations of the cobalt nitrate and urea working solutions [22]. The sample was denoted as Co-Al. The promotion of dry Со-Al catalyst was performed by incipient wetness impregnation with aqueous solutions of fac-Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 complex. The synthesis of such complex and its structural characterization are reported in [23]. Taking into account water capacity of the dry catalyst equal to 0.5cm3/g, concentrations of the working solutions were 14, 35 and 70g/l, which correspond to 0.2, 0.5 and 1.0wt.% Ru in the composition of Со-Al catalyst. The resulting promoted catalysts were dried at 50°C for 12h. The samples were denoted as Сo-Ru(0.2)Al, Сo-Ru(0.5)Al and Сo-Ru(1.0)Al. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 N2 physical adsorption at the liquid nitrogen temperature Textural characteristics of the calcined catalysts were assessed from N2 physical adsorption at the liquid nitrogen temperature using a TriStar II (3020) (Micromeritics, USA) automated volumetric adsorption unit. Helium was employed as the carrier gas. Specific surface area of the tested samples was determined by the multipoint BET method. Pore volume and size were calculated using the BJH model from adsorption-desorption isotherms at a relative pressure P/Po =0.99. Weight of the sample for analysis was 0.1–0.2g. Samples were degassed in vacuum at a temperature of 200°C for 2h. Relative error in determination of specific surface area was ±10%. 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction Diffraction experiments were carried out at room temperature on a D8 (Bruker, Germany) diffractometer with a copper anode as a source of CuKα radiation, wavelength λ=1.5418Å. Lattice parameters were refined and sizes of the coherent scattering region (CSR) were found in TOPAS software (Bruker, Germany) implementing the full-profile Rietveld method. Crystal lattice parameters were refined by positions of all available diffraction peaks. The CSR sizes were determined from the width of all diffraction lines taking into account their shape. 2.2.3 IR spectroscopy Diffuse reflectance IR Fourier spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu FTIR 8300 spectrometer with a DRS 8000 attachment. Diffuse reflectance spectra were taken in a range of 400–6000cm−1 with a resolution 4cm−1 and accumulation from 200 to 400 scans per each spectrum. The spectra were then transformed into the Kubelka-Munk scale F(R∞)=(1–R)2/(2R), where R is the reflection factor. IR transmission spectra were recorded with a KBr matrix on the same spectrometer without diffuse reflectance attachment using the same spectral range, resolution and accumulation of 100–200 scans. 2.2.4 Thermal analysis The reduction of cobalt catalysts under non-isothermal conditions was studied by thermal analysis, and thermogravimetry curves (TG, DTG) were recorded on a Netzsch STA 409 PC instrument. Measurements were made with the use of Pt-Ir crucibles. The weight of the sample was 100mg. Thermal curves for the samples were recorded in a range from 50 to 900°C at a 3°C/min heating rate in a mixture of argon and hydrogen. Hydrogen was fed at a rate of 20ml/min with simultaneous delivery of a shielding gas (argon) through a balance at a rate of 20ml/min. The total flow rate of gases around the sample was ca. 40ml/min. Buoyancy (the Archimedes force and viscous attrition of the gas flow) was accounted for by subtraction of the correction curve that was obtained before each measurement of kinetic reduction curve of the catalysts by recording TG and DTG curves of corundum with the same weight using the same heating rate, crucible and atmosphere. 2.2.5 XPS study An XPS study of the chemical composition of catalysts was performed on a SPECS Surface Nano Analysis GmbH (Germany) photoelectron spectrometer. The spectrometer was equipped with a hemispherical analyzer PHOIBOS-150, an X-ray monochromator FOCUS-500, an XR–50M source of X-ray characteristic radiation with the double Al/Ag anode, and a high-pressure cell enabling treatment of the samples by heating in gas mixtures at a pressure up to 5atm. The spectra were recorded using monochromatic Al Kα radiation (hn =1486.74eV). The binding energy (Eb) scale was calibrated by the internal standard method using the Al2p line of aluminum (Eb =74.4eV). Relative concentrations of elements in the analytical zone were determined from integrated intensities of XPS spectra taking into account photoionization cross-section of the corresponding terms [24]. A detailed analysis was made by deconvolution of the spectra into individual components. Accordingly, after background subtraction by the Shirley method [25], the experimental curve was deconvolved into several peaks corresponding to photoemission of electrons from atoms in different chemical environment. Data processing was made using the software package CasaXPS [26]. The shape of the peaks was approximated by a Voigt function (i.e. convolution of Gaussian and Lorentzian functions). Chemical composition of six samples was studied: Со-Ru(0.2)Al and Сo-Ru(1.0)Al catalysts, metallic Ru, ruthenium compound fac-Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3, and thermolysis products of this compound obtained at 270 and 410 °C in Ar medium and having a hypothetical composition of (RuNO)2O3 and RuO2, respectively [27]. Со-Ru(0.2)Al and Сo-Ru(1.0)Al catalysts, which were preliminarily pressed into pellets (diameter 8mm and thickness 1mm), were additionally studied after the reduction in hydrogen at different temperatures. The pelletized catalyst was treated directly in a high-pressure cell in a hydrogen atmosphere at 200, 300 and 400°C. After the reduction, the catalyst was transferred to the analytical chamber of the photoelectron spectrometer in vacuum to prevent contacting with air. 2.2.6 Electron microscopy The morphology of catalyst grains was studied on a JSM-6460LV (JEOL, Japan) scanning electron microscope at accelerating voltage of 20kV. The instrument was equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer Oxford INCA Energy that can estimate the content of components along the grain radius with the locality of 1–2μm. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained on an electron microscope JEM 2010 (JEOL, Japan) at accelerating voltage up to 200kV and limiting lattice resolution 0.14nm. Images were recorded using a CCD camera (Soft Imaging System, Germany). The device was equipped with an EDAX energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer and semiconductor Si(Li) detector to determine the composition of samples with the locality of ca. 10nm. The samples were deposited on the holey carbon substrates mounted on copper grids from ethanol suspension using a UZD-LUCh2 ultrasonic disperser to obtain a uniform distribution of the sample particles over the substrate surface. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalysts were tested in an uniaxial tubular reactor (Temkin reactor) 4mm in diameter with a fixed catalyst bed [28]. Catalyst granules represented by cylinders 2.5–3mm in diameter and 5–7mm in length alternated with alumina spheres 2.5–3mm in diameter and the total height of the bed was ca. 7cm. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was performed at the pressure of 2.1MPa, temperature 190 and 210°C, composition of the reaction mixture Н2:СО:N2 =6:3:1, and feed rate of the reaction mixture 2.6–4.4nl gcat −1 h−1. Catalytic activity of the samples was measured at CO conversion of 8–18%. The content of CO, H2, CH4, CO2 and N2 (internal standard) in the initial and final gas mixtures was determined quantitatively on a LHM-8MD gas chromatograph equipped with heat conductivity detector and packed column with activated carbon BAU. Gaseous products of the synthesis (C1-C8) were analyzed chromatographically on a Tsvet-530 instrument having a flame ionization detector (FID) and a capillary column with the stationary SiO2 phase. The composition of liquid C8+ hydrocarbons accumulated upon testing in condenser, in particular the aqueous fraction of the products as well as the liquid and solid products (C8-C40) accumulated in the reactor volume and extracted by hexane, was analyzed on a Tsvet-560 chromatograph (FID, capillary column with the stationary SE-54 phase). Before catalytic testing, the catalysts were activated in a flow reactor, first in an Ar medium at 300–350°C for 1.5h, and then in 100% hydrogen for 4h at the temperatures chosen from thermal analysis data (the maxima on DTG profiles corresponding to the maximum conversion rate and denoted as the characteristic reduction temperature). Isothermal calcination and reduction were preceded by a slow heating (2–5°C/min). The characteristic reduction temperature according to DTG data and the elemental composition of catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . Data on activation temperatures are listed in Table 4. The amount of surface cobalt and its dispersion in Сo-Al and Co-Ru(0.2)Al catalysts prereduced at 500 and 350 °C for 4h respectively was estimated at 50 °C from the dynamics of oxygen sorption from 100% N2O at the pulsed feeding of nitrous oxide [29]. The interaction of N2O with the catalyst is accompanied by its decomposition into nitrogen and oxygen, oxygen is rapidly adsorbed on the reduced cobalt atoms, while nitrogen is released to the gas phase: Сos +2N2Ogas →CoO2s + 2N2,gas ; therewith, one cobalt atom corresponds to two N2 molecules [30]. As shown by nitrous oxide pulse adsorption, the amount of surface cobalt νСо was 1.34×10−4 and 1.64×10−4 mol Co/gcat for Co-Al and Сo-Ru(0.2)Al, respectively, and dispersion of metallic cobalt was equal to 9.1 and 11.0%, respectively. These data can be used to calculate the specific surface area of cobalt, SСо: S C o = v C o ⋅ N A A C o o Assuming the surface density of cobalt atoms, ACo 0, equal to 1.52×1019 at./m2 (the average value over the faces of fcc structure: (110) − 1.13×1019, (100) − 1.59×1019, (111) − 1.84×1019) and the Avogadro number NA =6.022×1023 mol−1, SСо was found to be equal to 5.31 and 6.50m2/gcat for unpromoted and promoted catalysts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Texture of catalyst granules and spatial uniformity of Co and Ru distribution Data of elemental analysis of the dried samples are listed in Table 1. Cobalt content in all the dried samples varies from 9.14 to 9.53wt.%. Ru content in the modified samples is lower than the specified value by 6–10%. Different concentrations of Со and Ru are related to the presence of impurity anions and water in the catalysts. According to SEM and TEM data for the catalysts used in the process, cobalt and ruthenium are distributed nonuniformly in the granule. A more detailed discussion is presented below. Calcination in an Ar medium at 300–350°C for 1.5h produces weight losses of ca. 15%, and thermal conversion is accompanied by a release of water (18 a.m.u.), nitrogen oxide (30 a.m.u.) and carbon dioxide (44 a.m.u.) [22]. Weight content of cobalt in the Co-Al catalyst upon calcination is ca. 10.9wt.%. According to low-temperature nitrogen adsorption, the initial δ-Al2O3 has a developed specific surface area (104m2 g−1) with bimodal pore size distribution and characteristic diameters of ca. 9 and 25nm (see density functions of pore size distribution under the assumption of cylindrical pores in Fig. S1 of the Supporting information). Table 1 shows some textural characteristics of the support as well as Сo-Al and Сo-Ru(0.5)Al catalysts calcined at 350°C in an argon medium: specific surface area according to BET, pore volumes of the two fractions of the bimodal distribution, and the characteristic pore diameters. The introduction of active component increased the specific surface area by 11% and shifted the pore size distribution curve toward small diameters. The mean diameter of large pores decreased by ca. 40%, and volume by 31%; this indicates a stabilization of cobalt compounds in large pores. As shown by TEM data for the calcined Сo-Ru(1.0)Al sample, the support is morphologically heterogeneous and contains small crystallites represented by spheres and filaments, which are typical of γ- and δ-modifications of alumina, as well as the laminated particles with the size of ca. 20nm. Particles of the active component, cobalt-containing oxide with the spinel-like structure, also have quite a wide particle size distribution, from some nanometers to 10nm. Thus, the formation of oxide precursor of the active component proceeds in the existing pores of the support and does not produce dramatic changes in the overall texture; however, it increases the specific surface area by decreasing the pore volume and size. A further introduction of the promoter (the Ru complex) exerts only a minor effect on the textural characteristics and slightly decreases the specific surface area. Spatial distribution of cobalt and ruthenium in the catalyst granule was studied by EDAX in a combination with scanning and transmission electron microscopy. The study was performed with the Co-Ru(0.5)Al catalyst after its reduction and catalytic testing). As seen on the SEM image of the Co-Ru(0.5)Al catalyst grain spall (Fig. S2), impregnation of the granule with ruthenium produces a considerable nonuniformity in ruthenium distribution with its predominant concentration in the external layer whose thickness does not exceed 0.3mm. Such a distribution is quite typical of the impregnated catalysts. The introduction of cobalt by DPU method gives a much more uniform profile of the cobalt content: cobalt content in the external layer of the grain is nearly twofold higher than in its center. The observed excess of the average content of cobalt and ruthenium over the АES data may be due to the fact that metallic particles of heavy elements (cobalt and ruthenium) in the studied EDAX samples adsorb secondary and scattered electrons more efficiently, thus decreasing the interaction with the sample. Due to the difference in spatial distribution of Co and Ru, the Co:Ru ratio in the central part of the granule is much greater (above 80), than the average value over the granule (ca. 20, according to AES data). 3.2 Structure of the oxidized state of catalyst prior to reductive activation X-ray diffraction data for the catalysts and alumina used for their synthesis are displayed in Fig. 1 a. Alumina in the support is represented mostly by the δ-Al2O3 phase with a small admixture of γ-Al2O3 (see the [220] shoulder at 2θ=31.58° corresponding to d220 =2.83Å, and the [400] shoulder at 45.62° corresponding to d[400] =1.95Å). The diffraction pattern of the δ-Al2O3 phase is represented by a tetragonal structure (space group P 4 ¯ m 2 ) with the lattice parameters a =7.95(1) Å and c =23.40(1) Å, which agree with the data of PDF #16-0394 and the results reported in [31]. The refinement was made in the space group P41212 [31]. The average size of CSR is 8nm. Diffraction patterns of all the catalysts calcined at 300–350°C in an argon medium show the diffraction maxima at 2θ=18.9°, 31.2°, 36.8°, 44.8°, 59.4° and 65.2°, which correspond to interplane distances d111 =4.70Å, d220 =2.87Å, d311 =2.44Å, d400 =2.02Å, d511 =1.56Å and d440 =1.43Å and are attributed to the spinel-like structure. Lattice parameter (a) for the sample containing 1% ruthenium is 8.09(1) Å, while for other samples a =8.08(1)Å, and space group is Fd3m. This oxide phase can be represented by both the cobalt oxide Со3О4 and the mixed cobalt-aluminum oxide Со3-xAlxO4 (0≤x≤2); hereinafter it is denoted as Со3О4*. The fraction of Co3+ cations substituted by Al3+ cations in the spinel structure cannot be estimated from XRD data because Co-Al oxides with the spinel-like structure of different composition (Co3O4, CoAl2O4, Co2AlO4 and nonstoichiometric Co-Al oxides) have very close lattice parameters in the range of 8.07-8.10Å [32–34]. The average CSR size of the spinel-like phase determined from all the diffraction maxima is 6.3nm for Сo-Al, 5.4nm for Сo-Ru(0.2)Al, 5.1nm for Сo-Ru(0.5)Al, and 4.9nm for Сo-Ru(1.0)Al. Phases of ruthenium compounds were not detected by TEM and XRD either due to small amounts of the element or due to the presence of ruthenium in the X-ray amorphous state. IR diffuse reflectance spectra displayed in Fig. 2 give additional information on the local structure of calcined catalysts. A broad region of vibrations at 500–1000cm−1 with the maxima at 760 and 820cm−1 and a shoulder at 910cm−1 belong to vibrations of the δ-Al2O3 lattice [35]. Absorption bands in the regions of 566 and 668cm−1 and a weak band near 520cm−1, which is observed as a shoulder, are typical of Со3О4 and cobalt-alumina spinel СоAl2O4 [36]. High intensity of the background absorption in a wide region from 500 to 800cm−1 may testify, however, to nonstoichiometry of the spinel-like phase and a considerable inversion of the cationic distribution in the spinel structure, when Al3+ cations partially replace Co2+ in tetrahedral positions [37]. In this connection, the cobalt-containing oxide phase in the catalyst composition can be identified as nonstoichiometric oxide Со3-xAlxO4 (0≤x≤3) [38]. Weak absorption bands at 1385 and 1591cm−1 are retained in the catalyst structure after calcination in flowing Ar, which testifies to the presence of a small amount of nitrate and carbonate anions. The bands of impurity carbonate anions are clearly seen on the spectra recorded without KBr matrix (Fig. 2b) (a.b. 1339, 1407 and 1453cm−1), and their intensity is higher for the promoted sample. The spectra of the calcined and promoted Co-Ru(1.0)Al sample show vibrations at 1669 and 1890cm−1, which are absent in the spectrum of unpromoted sample and are typical of deformation vibrations of NH3 and NO groups [23]. Such vibrations can be assigned to ruthenium nitrosyl oxide (RuNO)2O3 with incomplete removal of ammonium ligands formed by thermolysis of the Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 complex in an inert gas at temperatures up to 260 °C [27]. Thus, according to XRD, DRIFT and TEM data, after thermal treatment of the catalysts in an Ar medium at 300–350°C, cobalt enters the composition of the Со3-xAlxO4 spinel-like phase, which contains impurity anions СО3 2−, NO3 − and ОН−. The average CSR size of this oxide is ca. 6.3nm with the distribution (according to TEM) in the range up to 10nm. The introduction of up to 1wt.% ruthenium did not produce a substantial effect on the phase composition and size of the crystallites. NO vibrations observed upon calcination of the Co-Ru(1.0)Al catalyst at 300°C are attributed to the thermolysis product of the Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 complex; calcination at a higher temperature, 450°C, results in the formation of RuO2 oxide. 3.3 Evolution of the composition and structure of the catalysts upon reduction The processes occurring in the course of reductive treatment of Сo-Al catalysts can be divided into two main steps associated with weight losses and denoted as I and II in DTG profiles in Fig. 3 . In our recent study [10], thermal analysis and in situ XRD were employed for a detailed investigation of structural transformations of the cobalt-containing oxide in the indicated catalysts upon reduction as well as the kinetics of these transformations and the effect of ruthenium promotion on kinetic parameters of the process. This study, whose details are omitted in the present work, allowed a conclusion that during the reductive treatment the Со3О4 * mixed cobalt-alumina oxide successively transforms to СоО* oxide at step (I) and to metallic cobalt at step (II). The promotion with ruthenium (up to 1wt.%) from the fac-Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 complex accelerates the reduction process and decreases the characteristic temperatures of both reduction steps, Со3+ →Со2+ and Со2+ →Со0; therewith, the temperature range of metallic cobalt formation shifts to lower temperatures by more than 250°C. The model-free analysis using Friedman and Ozawa-Flynn-Wall isoconversional methods revealed a considerable (ca. 25–40%) decrease in the apparent Ea at both steps of reduction for the promoted systems. Modeling of experimental kinetic dependences by regression analysis and estimation of the evolution of CSR sizes of cobalt-containing phases showed that the reduction of ruthenium promoted Co/δ-Al2O3 catalysts is sequential and consists of three steps: C o 3 + → A n 1 C o 2 + → A n 2 ( C o o , C o 2 + ) → D C o o The first step proceeds through the formation of several CoO* phase centers (including CoO) within one Co3O4* crystallite and is followed by their further growth, which is described by the Avrami–Erofeev kinetic model (An1) with n1 <1, which may indicate significant diffusion constraints of the CoO* nuclei growth. Several nuclei of the CoO* phase form several discrete domains from one Co3O4* crystallite. Stabilization of the highly dispersed state of CoO* may be ensured by aluminum cations that entered the composition of the initial Co3O4* and were displaced to interdomain boundary in the course of reduction. The second step is a kinetically controlled sequential process of the Co metal phase nucleation (An2) followed by the step of slow particle growth, which is limited by the diffusion of ions in the oxide according to the Jander model (D). At step D, ruthenium promotion leads to a joint decrease in the apparent activation energy and preexponential factor (obeying the linear expression of isokinetic (compensation) effect), which indicates a relaxation of diffusional limitations at the final step of cobalt reduction. In the case of unmodified Co/δ-Al2O3, the characteristic temperature of the metal phase formation reaches very high values at which the metal nuclei rapidly coalesce into larger ones. For ruthenium promoted catalysts, each CoO* crystallite generates one metal crystallite; thus, ruthenium enhances the dispersion of the active component at relatively low temperatures. At the optimal reduction temperatures, metallic cobalt has a defect structure represented by alternating domains with fcc and hcp structures. Thermal analysis and in situ XRD did not reveal the state of ruthenium in the course of reduction. Information on the ruthenium state can be obtained from XPS data. 3.4 Electronic state of cobalt and ruthenium according to XPS The XPS study of calcined (initial) and reduced promoted catalysts demonstrated the presence of Al, Co, Ru, O, C and N in subsurface layers. The Al2p spectra of oxide precursors of the catalyst show a peak with the binding energy 74.4eV, which corresponds to aluminum in the Al3+ state. In the literature, binding energies of Al2p for Al2O3 are in the range of 74.2–74.6eV [39–41]. Shape and position of the spectra did not change upon reduction of the catalysts at 200, 300 and 400°C. In this connection, the indicated line was used as the internal standard to take into account the charging effect (the С1s spectrum, which is commonly employed for this purpose, was inapplicable here due to overlapping with the intensive spectrum of Ru3d). Binding energies of Ru3d5/2 , Co2p3/2 and O1s for the studied catalysts are listed in Table 2 . Co2p spectra of the tested catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4 , frames a1 and b1. It is known that the 2p level of cobalt splits into two sublevels, Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 , due to the spin-orbital interaction. Accordingly, the Co2p spectra of the surface show the Co2p3/2 -Co2p1/2 doublet with a spin-orbital splitting of 15.4eV. Co2p spectra of the initial catalysts are well described by one Co2p3/2 -Co2p1/2 doublet with the Co2p3/2 binding energy in the region of 781.0eV and the corresponding intense shake-up satellites. The high binding energy and the presence of shake-up satellites indicate that cobalt is in the oxidized state. Hydrogen treatment results in the appearance of additional Co2p3/2 -Co2p1/2 doublet in the Co2p spectrum with the Co2p3/2 binding energy in the region of 778.0eV; asymmetric shape of the doublet indicates that cobalt is reduced to the Co0 state. According to the literature, Co0 has the Co2p3/2 binding energy in the range of 777.5–782.2eV [42–46]; Co2+ in CoO, 780.7–781.7eV [42,46,47]; and Co2+-Co3+ in Co3O4, 779.5–780.6eV [42,46,48,49]. Lines of the shake-up satellites are absent in the spectra of metallic cobalt, while in the spectrum of Co3O4 oxide they have a lower intensity as compared to the spectrum of CoO oxide. After treatment in hydrogen at 200°C, a great part of cobalt is in the Co2+ state. An increase in the temperature of hydrogen treatment increases the integrated intensity of photoemission peaks typical of metallic cobalt but decreases intensity of the peaks corresponding to cobalt in the oxidized state; however, the intensity is retained up to the reduction temperature of 400°C (Fig. 4, Table 2). Thus, XPS data confirm that treatment in hydrogen leads to incomplete reduction of cobalt from Co3O4 * oxide to the Co0 state. In Supporting information, Fig. S3a displays the overlapping C1s and Ru3d spectra of the initial CoRu(1.0)Al catalyst. The spectrum shows an intensive C1s peak in the region of 284.8eV, which corresponds to hydrocarbon admixtures. Fig. S3b displays the C1s and Ru3d spectra of powdered metallic ruthenium after purification of the surface by argon ions and spectra of the thermolysis product of fac-Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 complex at 270°C (supposedly (RuNO)2O3). It is known that the 3d level of ruthenium splits into two sublevels, Ru3d5/2 and Ru3d3/2 , due to spin-orbital interaction. Accordingly, the Ru3d spectra show the Ru3d5/2 -Ru3d3/2 doublet whose spin-orbital splitting is 4.12eV. According to the literature, ruthenium in the metallic state Ru0 has Ru3d5/2 binding energies in the range of 279.5–280.1eV [50]; Ru4+ in RuO2, 280.7–280.9eV [51,52]; Ru3+ in RuCl3, 281.9 [53]; and in Ru(NH3)6Br3, 283.0eV [54]. The evolution of Ru3d spectra during the reduction of CoRu(0.2)Al and CoRu(1.0)Al catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 4, frames a2 and b2. Ru3d spectra of oxide precursors of the catalysts are well described by one Ru3d5/2 -Ru3d3/2 doublet with the Ru3d5/2 binding energy near 282.4eV. A higher binding energy of Ru3d5/2 indicates that ruthenium is in the oxidized state. The observed binding energies closely correspond to the binding energy of Ru3d5/2 in thermolysis products of fac- Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 complex (see Table S1 in Supporting information). Under the assumption that upon calcination of promoted dry samples at 350°C and thermolysis of fac-Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 ruthenium complex at 270°C the ruthenium compound is represented by ruthenium nitrosyl oxide [Ru(NO)]2O3, the observed binding energy corresponds to the complex cation [Ru(NO)]3+ (the electronic structure of nitrosyl complexes is discussed in the review [55]). After treatment in hydrogen at 200°C, Ru3d spectra are described by two Ru3d5/2 -Ru3d3/2 doublets with Ru3d5/2 binding energies of ca. 279.9 and 281.4eV, which indicate the decomposition of the nitrosyl complex and a possible reduction of ruthenium to the cation with a lower oxidation state. The reduction of RuNO(NO3)3 compound in 100% hydrogen was studied in [56]. The authors of the cited work think that ruthenium in the initial compound has the oxidation state 4+ and turns upon reduction to the metallic state through the intermediate oxidation states 3+ and 2+ with the corresponding binding energies: Ru4+, 283.1; Ru3+, 282.3; Ru2+, 281.3; and Ru0, 279.9eV. Data on the stepwise reduction of the oxide ruthenium compound RuO2 were obtained in the study of the reduction of Ru promoted silica-supported Co catalysts by in situ XAS [9]. Simulation of XAS spectra allowed the authors to demonstrate that ruthenium transforms upon reduction from RuO2 (4+) to the metal (0) through the formation of an intermediate with the oxidation state 3+. The Ru3d5/2 peak in the region of lower binding energies (279–280eV) certainly corresponds to ruthenium in the metallic state (the low binding energy and asymmetric shape of the peak). After a further reduction of the CoRu(1.0)Al catalyst at 300 and 400°C, the Ru3d spectrum is described by one Ru3d5/2 -Ru3d3/2 doublet with the Ru3d5/2 binding energy in the region of 279.9eV, which testifies to a complete reduction of ruthenium to metallic state. In the case of CoRu(0.2)Al catalyst, a further treatment at 300 and 400 °C also results in a complete reduction of ruthenium to metallic state. Therewith, the Ru3d spectrum is described by two Ru3d5/2 -Ru3d3/2 doublets with the Ru3d5/2 binding energy in the region of 279.2–279.4 and 279.9eV, which may be related to the formation of individual metallic ruthenium particles and the particles consisting of the cobalt-ruthenium alloy. Relative atomic concentrations of elements upon reduction are listed in Table 3 . Treatment in hydrogen at 200 °C increases atomic ratios [Ru]/[Al] and especially [Co]/[Al], which may be caused by decomposition of the nitrosyl ruthenium complex and reduction of the spinel-like oxide Сo3O4* to CoO* accompanied by dispersion of the cobalt-containing phase of the catalyst [10,57]. Reduction of the Co-Ru(1.0)Al catalyst at temperatures up to 300–400°C considerably increases the [Ru]/[Co] ratio but decreases [Co]/[Al]. These data cannot be attributed to the formation of bimetallic Co-Ru particles since the surface of such particles is enriched with cobalt due to segregation with the heat of ca. 19.5kJ/mol [58]. Thus, it should be supposed that metallic ruthenium enters the composition of metallic cobalt particles only partially, and its considerable part forms the individual phase on the alumina surface or on the oxide layer decorating the metallic cobalt particles. It should be noted, however, that XPS data give no grounds to suppose the formation of an individual phase of metallic ruthenium in the case of CoRu(0.2)Al catalyst. 3.5 Elemental composition and structure of the active state of catalysts Being drawn out from the reactor of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, the catalysts look as black granules covered with a film of the synthesis products, solid paraffins. Products of the synthesis passivate the catalyst and protect the active component against oxidation with air, even after extraction of the products in hexane. According to XRD data, Сo-Al, Сo-Ru(0.2)Al and Сo-Ru(1.0)Al catalysts after catalysis comprise several phases (Fig. 1b). For convenience, XRD pattern of the support was superposed on patterns of the catalysts. The shoulder at 44.3° and diffraction maxima at 51.2 and 75.8° testify to the presence of metallic cobalt with fcc structure (the diffraction from (111), (200) and (220), respectively) and lattice parameter 3.54 Å in the samples. The average CSR size of metallic cobalt phase for all the samples was calculated from the 111 diffraction maximum and was equal to 5.5nm. If domains with the hcp structure are present in metallic cobalt particles, they are very thin (a weak shoulder at 47.6° can be attributed to diffraction in the [101]hcp direction and d=1.91Å). A weak maximum in the region of 42.4° may indicate the presence of cobalt in the oxidized state CoO* (d200 =2.13Å). The presence of the Co3-xAlxO4 spinel phase can be indicated by scattering in the region of the peak by ∼65°. The presence of cobalt-containing oxides agrees with XPS data. Diffraction maxima at 21.5 and 24.0° (d110 =4.13 and d200 =3.72Å, respectively) should be assigned to crystalline paraffin, space group Pnam (PDF # 40–1995). According to TEM, all the catalysts under consideration have dispersed metallic cobalt particles uniformly distributed on the support surface; the prevailing size of the particles is 5–8nm, but some of the particles have the size of 15–20nm (Fig. 5 a, b). Metal particles may be covered with the oxide layer having the spinel-like structure: interplane distances 2.05Å correspond to (111)fcc of Co, while 2.40, 2.47 and 2.42Å can be attributed to (311) of Co-Al oxide or δ-Al2O3 support, 5.42Å should be assigned to (011) of the δ-Al2O3 support (Fig. 5a). Large particles of cobalt-containing phases with the size greater than 10nm are represented by coherently alternating domains of metallic cobalt with fcc and hcp structures (Fig. 5f). The absence of a distinct XRD maximum in the region of diffraction from (101)hcp, which was noted above when discussing X-ray diffraction data, indicates that the large particles contain thin domains of metallic cobalt with hcp structure. In the СoRu(1.0)-Al catalyst, nonuniformity of the cobalt particle size distribution is visually more pronounced (Fig. 5d). ЕDX in a combination with TEM did not detect the particles with a considerable amount of ruthenium in the Co-Ru(0.2)Al catalyst. At a higher Ru content, 0.5–1.0wt.%, Ru was found to enter the composition of the cobalt-containing oxide phase or reside at the interface “metallic cobalt – oxide phase”: interplane distance 2.21Å in Fig. 5e can be attributed to the (111) plane, while d=2.51 (Fig. 5f) and 2.58Å (Fig. 5e) to the (101) plane of ruthenium oxide phase RuО2. EDX data indicate that Ru content is higher in the surface layer of metallic particle decorated by the oxide. Interplane distances 2.13 and 2.14Å (d002) as well as 2.35Å (d100) in Fig. 5c, e, which correspond to the metallic Ru phase, testify to the presence of individual ultradispersed ruthenium particles with the size of ca. 1nm on the support surface. A correlation between Co and Ru contents, expressed as Ru/Al and Со/Al weight ratios according to EDX, is displayed in Fig. 6 . The measurements were made with the samples obtained by grinding of a whole catalyst granule (circles) and a scrape from its external part (triangles). EDX spectra were taken from different regions of the sample with different amounts of metallic particles, which determines a significant spread in the ratio of transition metals (Co and Ru) and aluminum; however, Со and Ru contents correlate with each other. Due to the above noted difference in the spatial distribution of cobalt and ruthenium, it is not surprising that the ratio in the external part is shifted toward enrichment with ruthenium. Noteworthy is the high Co:Ru ratio in the regions of Co-Ru(1.0)Al catalyst where metallic cobalt particles are concentrated (Fig. 6c). This ratio differs only slightly from the corresponding values for Co-Ru(0.2)Al catalyst containing a 5-fold smaller amount of ruthenium, and is equal to ca. 20 (ca. 10 in the external part of the grain). For the regions with Со:Al>1, Со and Ru contents are proportional to each other (lines of direct proportionality are marked in the Figures). On the other hand, in the regions with a low Со:Al ratio, the Сo:Ru ratio is much smaller. Such regions with a low cobalt content but relatively high ruthenium content are present also in the Co-Ru(0.5)Al catalyst, but were not detected in Co-Ru(0.2)Al. In our opinion, these data confirm the assumptions based on XPS data that upon promotion of the Со-Al catalyst with a small amount of ruthenium (0.2wt.%) virtually the entire ruthenium enters the composition of Со-Ru metallic nanoparticles; however, when the amount of introduced ruthenium is increased to 0.5 and especially to 1.0wt.%, its considerable part forms the individual phase of metallic ruthenium. EXAFS spectroscopy can give more data on formation of the mixed Co-Ru metallic particles. Several groups of researchers concluded the formation of Co-Ru phase basing on the EXAFS/XANES data. Iglesia et al. reported the Ru K-edge EXAFS radial distribution functions for Co-Ru/TiO2 (0.14% Ru, 11.6% Co) reduced at 500°C and calcined at various temperatures prior to the reduction [59]. They observed decrease of the intensity of the peak at Ru-Ru interatomic distance of 2.6Å and appearence of the peak at 2.02Å, which is characteristic of Co-Ru distance, while increasing the temperature of Co-Ru sample calcination. These changes in Ru radial distribution functions show interaction of Co and Ru and formation of intermetallic particles. Authors supposed that significant part of Ru remains in monometallic particles, since the Ru-Ru coordination number doesn't decrease (ca. 6.0–6.3), while Ru-Co coordination increases from 2.9 to 5.9 at increasing the calcination temperature. EXAFS and XANES studies of 0.27%Ru–25%Co/Al2O3 [60] have shown that Ru significantly promotes reduction of cobalt: after the reduction in H2 350°C the Co–Co coordination number in the cobalt metal for promoted catalyst achieved 5.2 and was much higher than that of the unpromoted catalyst (ca. 1.4). Ru K edge EXAFS showed the decrease in the main distance for the first shell metal coordination (as well as for the next three shells) and, therefore, suggested that a major fraction of Ru was embedded in the metallic cobalt particles. In certain conditions, Co may enter the Ru metallic particles. In recent EXAFS study of 0.1-2.0% Ru/10%Co/silica catalysts [61], prepared by consecutive impregnation method, the authors have concluded that Co-Ru intermetallic particles are solid solution of 10–23% at. of Co in hexagonal ruthenium. This brief review shows an agreement between the published EXAFS studies and the discussed above XPS and EDAX data: major part of ruthenium is embedded in bimetallic Ru-Co particles. Taking into consideration the conclusions of the article [61], the «individual» Ru particles may also contain some cobalt. 3.6 Catalytic properties of ruthenium promoted Со-Al catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Conditions of reductive activation before testing in FTS were chosen from the data on temperature ranges of cobalt reduction in the catalysts. We think that at the chosen temperatures of activation in argon and then in hydrogen, the fractions of cobalt reduced to metallic state in promoted and unpromoted catalysts are close. Results of the testing are listed in Table 4 . The activity of ruthenium promoted catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis after 24h of catalytic testing was comparable with the activity of unpromoted catalyst (for 0.2 and 0.5 at.% Ru catalysts the activity was lower by 20%, while for the Сo-Ru(1.0)Al catalyst the activity was the same within experimental error). A comparison of the observed activity of the catalysts with their adsorption capacity toward oxygen (duringN2O decomposition) allowed us to estimate TOFCO, which was equal to 1.6×10−2 s−1 for Co-Al catalyst at 210°C, and 1.8×10−2 s−1 for Сo-Ru(0.2)Al. The indicated values are close to the literature data for TOFCO of Со-containing catalyst (for example, in [62] TOFCO =1.5–3×10−2 s−1 for a large series of supported Co catalyst at 200°C, Pmixture =2MPa). Thus, promotion of the catalyst with ruthenium from the nitrate-amine complex of nitrosyl ruthenium makes it possible to decrease the temperature of reductive activation from 500 to 330–350 °C without a loss or with a small loss in specific activity of the catalyst. It cannot be ruled out that the activation temperatures chosen for Сo-Ru(0.2)Al and Сo-Ru(0.5)Al catalysts are not quite optimal, and a slight increase in the temperature would enhance their activity. Therewith, the promoted catalysts showed a much higher selectivity for α-olefins, which are the primary products of the FTS, and for iso-alkanes (see also Fig. 7 ). An essential distinctive feature of ruthenium promoted samples is a much higher value of the αASF parameter, which attains 0.93–0.94 at 190°C. No differences were found in the molecular-weight distribution of alcohols in the aqueous fraction of the reaction products for promoted and unpromoted catalysts: it is well described by the ASF distribution with parameter αalcohols ∼0.52. As follows from the catalytic testing data, ultradispersed metallic ruthenium particles in Co-Ru(0.5)Al and Сo-Ru(1.0)Al catalysts do not show a significant intrinsic activity in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. This is expected in view of the studies [63] indicating a sharp drop in specific activity of ultradispersed metals of group VIII at the particle size smaller than 4–5nm due to their low ability to dissociatively adsorb CO. However, the presence of ruthenium in the catalyst not only decreased the reduction temperature but also modified the catalytic properties of the active particles of metallic cobalt by increasing its selectivity for olefins and high-molecular hydrocarbons without a considerable loss in the catalyst activity. Some other mechanisms of the observed effect of the promotion by Ru on the selectivity can be supposed. Adding Ru could alter the mean or prevailing size of the metallic cobalt particles. The XRD data on CSR and direct TEM-graphs of the catalysts after the catalytic tests don’t show any significant difference in cobalt particles size distribution between Ru-promoted and unpromoted catalysts. Therefore, although we can’t rule out that the effect of Ru-promotion on the selectivity is related to the size of cobalt particles, we still can’t suppose such influence. Another plausible reason for the selectivity enhancement by adding ruthenium may be related to mere narrowing the pores of the supporting oxide (see Fig. S1) and making the diffusion constrains more severe. Earlier, Iglesia proposed the control of diffusion constrains as one of the effective ways for adjusting the catalyst selectivity [62]. In our study, the observed narrowing is not dramatic: the bimodal distribution maxima shifted from 15 and 7nm to 13 and 6nm. Therefore, we can’t propose this as the reason for the observed effect. 4 Conclusion The promotion of cobalt-containing catalysts supported on δ-Al2O3 with ruthenium from the fac-Ru(NO)(NH3)2(NO3)3 complex provides a substantial decrease in their reduction temperature. Reductive activation under the conditions ensuring the formation of a comparable fraction of metallic cobalt increased selectivity of the promoted catalysts for α-olefins and high-molecular hydrocarbons without neither considerable loss, nor an improvement in the catalytic activity. Therefore, the observed in earlier studies significant enhancement of the activity of Co-Ru catalysts in the FTS should be related with the increase in the fraction of cobalt that was reduced to metallic state due to the effect of ruthenium on the reductive activation of Co-Al catalysts. Therewith, in the catalysts containing 0.5–1.0wt.% Ru, a part of ruthenium forms individual ultradispersed metallic ruthenium particles with the size of ca. 1nm, which are located on the surface of the oxide support. However, catalytic testing demonstrated that such particles do not show a noticeable activity in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The oxide layer decorating the surface of metallic cobalt particles is also strongly enriched with ruthenium. In the catalyst containing 0.2wt.% Ru, the major part of ruthenium enters the composition of metallic cobalt particles. Although the ruthenium-cobalt alloy segregates with enrichment of the surface with cobalt, the presence of ruthenium in metallic particles and probably in the decorating oxide layer exerts a considerable effect on selectivity of the catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The paper presents the low-temperature nitrogen adsorption, TG, XRD, IR spectroscopy, XPS, TEM and SEM data for ruthenium promoted (0.2–1wt.%) Сo-δAl2O3 catalysts and characteristics of the catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis after their activation under the conditions ensuring the reduction of comparable fractions of metallic cobalt. It was shown that cobalt in oxide precursors is a component of the spinel-like Со3-xAlxO4 phase containing the impurity anions СО3 2−, NO3 −, ОН−, and NO in promoted samples, which belong to the thermolysis product of the Ru precursor. Average sizes of Со3-xAlxO4 crystallites are in a range of 5–10nm. As ruthenium content in the catalyst increases upon reduction, the temperature of metallic phase formation decreases substantially (by more than 150°C). After the reduction, selectivity of promoted catalysts for α-olefins and high-molecular hydrocarbons was higher in comparison with unpromoted catalysts, without a noticeable decrease in catalytic activity. Therewith, in 0.5–1.0wt.% catalysts, a part of ruthenium forms individual ultradispersed metallic particles ca. 1nm in size that are located on the surface of oxide support and are not active in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The oxide layer decorating the surface of metallic cobalt particles is also strongly enriched with ruthenium. In the 0.2wt.% catalyst, the major part of ruthenium resides in metallic cobalt particles. Although the ruthenium-cobalt alloy segregates with enrichment of the surface with cobalt, the presence of ruthenium in the metallic particles and probably in the decorating oxide layer exerts a considerable effect on selectivity of the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: δ-Alumina supported cobalt catalysts promoted by ruthenium for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis
